metadata.case_name: State of Bihar & Mahesh Desai v. Ram Naresh Pandey & Anr.

facts.text: Murder of Nand Kumar Chaubey, a peon of Bagdigi colliery, committed in the course of a serious riot on February 20, 1954, resulting from differences between two rival labour-unions in connection with a strike.

Prosecution launched on first information report (FIR) of Ram Naresh Pandey against 28 persons, including Mahesh Desai under s.302/109 IPC for abetting the murder by speeches and exhortations at meetings or group-talks the day previous to the murder.

In FIR, Mahesh Desai held meetings advocating closing Bagdigi cable plant and colliery plant and assaulting dalals; on Friday morning exhorted labourers to stop work; evening meeting at 6:30 p.m. collected 120-125 labourers, exhorted to prevent work resumption; near Jeep said 'It is necessary for us to finish the dalals for achieving victory. You remain prepared for this.' and 'Finish all. What will happen will be seen.'
FIR information about Mahesh Desai's exhortations at 6:30 p.m. and 7:30 p.m. based on Jadubans Tiwary, who heard from Sheoji Singh and Ramdhar Singh.

Application for withdrawal by Public Prosecutor against Mahesh Desai only on December 6, 1954, when matter pending before Subordinate Judge-Magistrate of Dhanbad in committal stage, before any evidence taken.
Withdrawal application grounded on evidence available being meagre, only single item of dubious nature unlikely to establish prima facie case, not just and expedient to proceed.
Magistrate granted consent to withdrawal, discharged Mahesh Desai under s.494 CrPC.
Order upheld by Sessions Judge on revision petition filed jointly by first informant Ram Naresh Pandey and widow of murdered person.
High Court (Chief Justice) set aside discharge order in revision, opining no judicial exercise of discretion by Magistrate, directed Magistrate to record evidence and consider prima facie case.
Appeals to Supreme Court: by Advocate-General of State against High Court order; by Mahesh Desai by special leave.
No additional material beyond FIR and police statements indicated by private complainants.

legal_issues.text: Whether, where application for withdrawal under s.494 CrPC made on ground of insufficiency or meagreness of reliable evidence, it is improper exercise of discretion for Court to grant consent before evidence taken, if reasonably satisfied that evidence not likely to result in conviction.
Whether s.494 CrPC applies to committal stage (preliminary inquiry) in Sessions triable case.

petitioner_arguments.text: Public Prosecutor has executive discretion to withdraw subject to Court's consent; Court exercises judicial discretion to check if executive function improperly exercised or interferes with normal course of justice for illegitimate reasons; not required to determine triable issue on judicial evidence before consent.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.494 CrPC; Bawa Faqir Singh v. King Emperor (1938) L.R. 65 I.A. 388

petitioner_arguments.text: s.494 wide enough to cover preliminary inquiry stage in Sessions cases; no distinction between inquiry and trial limiting it to trial stage.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.494 CrPC; history of section from 1872, 1882, 1898 Codes

respondent_arguments.text: Where withdrawal sought on ground of no/meagre evidence, Court must record evidence judicially before granting consent, akin to s.202 CrPC inquiry; otherwise surrenders function to Public Prosecutor.

s.494 not applicable at committal stage in Sessions case; applies only after case reaches trial stage, as per wording 'in cases tried by jury before verdict, in other cases before judgment'; 'tried' excludes inquiry.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.494 CrPC; s.4(k) CrPC definition of inquiry; English nolle prosequi practice

court_reasoning.text: s.494 enables Public Prosecutor discretion to withdraw subject to Court's consent; Court satisfies itself executive function not improperly exercised or for illegitimate purposes; not to make prima facie determination on judicial evidence; initiative with Prosecutor.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Judicial discretion under s.494 not limited to material gathered judicially; wide language not narrowed.

court_reasoning.text: Public Prosecutor as officer of Court bound to assist with fair view; primary responsibility for prosecution on executive; Magistrate's role supplementary to prevent abuse.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Consent not lightly given but after scrutiny of grounds; can be for reasons beyond judicial prospects.

court_reasoning.text: On facts, evidence against Mahesh Desai meagre (FIR hearsay via Jadubans Tiwary from others); no better material shown; no impropriety in Prosecutor's view or Court's consent.
s.494 applies at any stage including committal (preliminary inquiry) in Sessions cases; 'tried' not limited to post-inquiry stage; history confirms wide scope covering all inquiries/trials.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No discrimination intended between jury/non-jury cases at inquiry stage.

holdings.text: Court may grant consent under s.494 CrPC before evidence recorded, if satisfied on available material (e.g., FIR, police statements) that withdrawal not improper and evidence unlikely to convict.
s.494 CrPC applicable at committal stage in Sessions triable cases.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bawa Faqir Singh v. The King Emperor
precedents_cited.relevance: s.494 gives general executive discretion to Public Prosecutor subject to Court consent on many grounds.
Withdrawal may be for reasons not confined to judicial prospects of prosecution.
Withdrawal may be for reasons not confined to judicial prospects of prosecution.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs withdrawal by Public Prosecutor with Court consent resulting in discharge/acquittal; judicial discretion to prevent abuse; distinguished from trial provisions.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Prosecution for murder and abetment thereof.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed appeals by State and Mahesh Desai, set aside High Court order, restored Magistrate's order granting consent to withdrawal and discharging Mahesh Desai.
outcome.relief_granted: Discharge of Mahesh Desai restored; prosecution against him withdrawn.

key_quotes.text: "Section 494 of the Code of Criminal Procedure gives a general executive discretion to the Public Prosecutor to withdraw from the prosecution subject to the consent of the Court, which may be determined on many possible grounds."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of s.494 as executive discretion checked judicially.

key_quotes.text: "The judicial function, therefore, implicit in the exercise of the judicial discretion for granting the consent would normally mean that the Court has to satisfy itself that the executive function of the Public Prosecutor has not been improperly exercised."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits Court's role to preventing abuse, not pre-trial determination.

key_quotes.text: "This is not a case where there is no evidence on the contrary, this is a case where there is evidence which requires judicial consideration."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: High Court view rejected; consent valid pre-evidence.
